message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the upper GI contrast series suggests incomplete intestinal rotation, which can lead to volvulus or obstruction of the duodenum or small intestine. Failure of duodenal recanalization would result in duodenal atresia or stenosis, while arrested rotation of ventral pancreatic bud can cause pancreas divisum. Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter are associated with pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of bilious vomiting in a 2-week-old infant suggests a surgical emergency. The upper GI contrast series indicates incomplete intestinal rotation, which is the most likely cause of the patient's condition. Failure of duodenal recanalization would present with double bubble sign on abdominal X-ray. Arrested rotation of ventral pancreatic bud would present as an annular pancreas. Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter would present as pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the upper GI contrast series suggests that the infant has malrotation of the intestine, which can cause duodenojejunal junction to be to the right of the vertebral midline and an air-filled cecum in the right upper quadrant. Failure of duodenal recanalization is associated with duodenal atresia, and arrested rotation of ventral pancreatic bud is associated with pancreas divisum. Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter is associated with pyloric stenosis, which would present with projectile vomiting within the first few weeks of life, but not bilious vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of bilious vomiting and the imaging finding of abnormal duodenal position suggest incomplete intestinal rotation. Failure of duodenal recanalization may cause duodenal atresia, which presents earlier with double bubble sign. Arrested rotation of ventral pancreatic bud may result in pancreatic divisum, which is usually asymptomatic. Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter may cause pyloric stenosis, which typically presents at 3-5 weeks of age with projectile non-bilious vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of bilious vomiting, inconsolable crying, and abnormal position of the duodenojejunal junction and cecum suggest incomplete intestinal rotation, which is the most likely cause of the patient's condition. Failure of duodenal recanalization would manifest as vomiting and distention soon after birth. Arrested rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud may cause pancreatitis but not bilious vomiting. Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter is a cause of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which would present with non-bilious vomiting and a palpable mass in the epigastric region.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of bilious vomiting and abnormal placement of the duodenojejunal junction suggests incomplete intestinal rotation, which is a malformation of midgut rotation. Failure of duodenal recanalization, arrested rotation of ventral pancreatic bud, and hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter are not likely to present with this clinical picture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging findings suggest that the baby has malrotation with midgut volvulus. Option B, incomplete intestinal rotation, is the most likely cause of malrotation with midgut volvulus. Failure of duodenal recanalization and arrested rotation of ventral pancreatic bud do not cause malrotation. Option D, hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter, is associated with pyloric stenosis, which presents with projectile non-bilious vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and results of the upper GI contrast series suggest incomplete intestinal rotation, which can lead to midgut volvulus and occlusion. Failure of duodenal recanalization can lead to duodenal atresia, which does not cause malrotation. Arrested rotation of ventral pancreatic bud may cause annular pancreas, but not malrotation. Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter cause pyloric stenosis, which presents with non-bilious vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the upper GI contrast series findings suggests incomplete intestinal rotation. Failure of duodenal recanalization would cause duodenal atresia, while hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter would cause pyloric stenosis. Arrested rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud is not a known condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of bilious vomiting and the imaging findings suggest incomplete intestinal rotation, which can cause a condition called malrotation leading to volvulus and intestinal obstruction. Failure of duodenal recanalization, arrested rotation of ventral pancreatic bud, and hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter are all less likely causes of the patient’s symptoms.
